column3: Where had they come from?

column2: Smerdyakov had picked them up and brought them in the day before.
column3: Smerdyakov had picked them up and brought them in the day before.

column2: Well, my lad, I've never met any one like you, Fyodor Pavlovitch said shortly, and gave him ten roubles.
column3: Well, my lad, I've never met any one like you, Fyodor Pavlovitch said shortly, and gave him ten roubles.

column2: We may add that he not only believed in his honesty, but had, for some reason, a liking for him, although the young man looked as morosely at him as at every one and was always silent. He rarely spoke.
column3: We may add that he not only believed in his honesty, but had, for some reason, a liking for him, although the young man looked as morosely at him as at every one and was always silent. He rarely spoke.

column2: If it had occurred to any one to wonder at the time what the young man was interested in, and what was in his mind, it would have been impossible to tell by looking at him.
column3: If it had occurred to any one to wonder at the time what the young man was interested in, and what was in his mind, it would have been impossible to tell by looking at him.

column2: Yet he used sometimes to stop suddenly in the house, or even in the yard or street, and would stand still for ten minutes, lost in thought.
column3: Yet he used sometimes to stop suddenly in the house, or even in the yard or street, and would stand still for ten minutes, lost in thought.

column2: A physiognomist studying his face would have said that there was no thought in it, no reflection, but only a sort of contemplation.
column3: A physiognomist studying his face would have said that there was no thought in it, no reflection, but only a sort of contemplation.

column2: There is a remarkable picture by the painter Kramskoy, called "Contemplation." There is a forest in winter, and on a roadway through the forest, in absolute solitude, stands a peasant in a torn kaftan and bark shoes.
column3: There is a remarkable picture by the painter Kramskoy, called "Contemplation." There is a forest in winter, and on a roadway through the forest, in absolute solitude, stands a peasant in a torn kaftan and bark shoes.

column2: He stands, as it were, lost in thought.
column3: He stands, as it were, lost in thought.

column2: Yet he is not thinking; he is "contemplating." If any one touched him he would start and look at one as though awakening and bewildered.
column3: Yet he is not thinking; he is "contemplating." If any one touched him he would start and look at one as though awakening and bewildered.

column2: It's true he would come to himself immediately; but if he were asked what he had been thinking about, he would remember nothing.
column3: It's true he would come to himself immediately; but if he were asked what he had been thinking about, he would remember nothing.

column2: Yet probably he has, hidden within himself, the impression which had dominated him during the period of contemplation.
column3: Yet probably he has, hidden within himself, the impression which had dominated him during the period of contemplation.

column2: Those impressions are dear to him and no doubt he hoards them imperceptibly, and even unconsciously.
column3: Those impressions are dear to him and no doubt he hoards them imperceptibly, and even unconsciously.

column2: How and why, of course, he does not know either.
column3: How and why, of course, he does not know either.

column2: He may suddenly, after hoarding impressions for many years, abandon everything and go off to Jerusalem on a pilgrimage for his soul's salvation, or perhaps he will suddenly set fire to his native village, and perhaps do both.
column3: He may suddenly, after hoarding impressions for many years, abandon everything and go off to Jerusalem on a pilgrimage for his soul's salvation, or perhaps he will suddenly set fire to his native village, and perhaps do both.

column2: There are a good many "contemplatives" among the peasantry.
column3: There are a good many "contemplatives" among the peasantry.

column2: Well, Smerdyakov was probably one of them, and he probably was greedily hoarding up his impressions, hardly knowing why.
column3: Well, Smerdyakov was probably one of them, and he probably was greedily hoarding up his impressions, hardly knowing why.
